Award.AwardTitle: Rigidity Phenomena in Geometry and Dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dynamical systems and ergodic theory investigate the evolution of a physical or mathematical system over time, such as turbulence in a fluid flow or changing planetary systems. New ideas and concepts such as information, entropy, chaos and fractals have changed our understanding of the world. Dynamics and ergodic theory provide excellent mathematical tools, and have a strong impact on the sciences and engineering. Symbolic dynamics for example has been instrumental in developing efficient and safe codes for computer science. Tools and ideas from smooth dynamics are used as far afield as cell biology and meteorology. Geometry is a highly developed and ancient field in mathematics of amazing vigor. It studies curves, surfaces and their higher dimensional analogues, their shapes, shortest paths, and maps between such spaces. Differential geometry had its roots in cartography, starting with Gauss in the nineteenth century. It is closely linked with physics and other sciences and applied areas such as computer vision. Geometry and dynamics are closely related. Indeed, important dynamical systems come from geometry, and vice versa geometry provides tools to study dynamical systems. One main goal of this project studies when two dynamical systems commute, i.e. when one system is unaffected by the changes brought on by the other. Alternatively, these are systems with unexpected symmetries Important examples of such systems arise from geometry when the space contains many flat subspaces. Group theory finally enters both dynamics and geometry by studying the group of symmetries of a geometry or dynamical situation, or by investigating the dynamical and geometric behavior of the group of symmetries acting on a space.

This project centers on problems between dynamical systems, group theory and geometry. There are two main goals: First, establish exponential mixing properties for several different systems in dynamics, in particular frame flows from Riemannian geometry and solenoids coming from noninvertible systems. The principal investigator (PI) will draw tools from dynamics, geometry and number theory to accomplish these goals. Second, prove rigidity properties in geometry and in dynamical systems, in particular when the system and spaces in question are "higher rank", e.g. when spaces have flat subspaces or the dynamics has nontrivially commuting elements. Such systems appear naturally in seemingly quite separate areas, for example in number theory or in studying the spectrum of the Laplacian. The investigator will work on rigidity properties of actions of higher rank abelian and semi-simple Lie groups and their lattices striving to classify such systems under suitable geometric or dynamical hypotheses. The PI will employ tools from geometry, dynamics, Lie groups, and specifically exponential mixing properties. The PI will also investigate discrete faithful representations of hyperbolic groups in p-adic Lie groups, equilibrium states for partially hyperbolic dynamical systems and spherical higher rank in Riemannian geometry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award lies between dynamical systems, group theory and geometry. The PI studied dynamical and geometric structures of "higher rank" systems in these areas. These appear naturally in seemingly quite separate areas, for example in number theory or in studying the spectrum of the Laplacian. The investigator worked on rigidity properties of actions of higher rank abelian and semi-simple Lie groups and their lattices striving to classify such systems under suitable geometric or dynamical hypotheses.  In addition, the investigator also analyzed Riemannian manifolds (especially those of higher hyperbolic rank). Geometric, dynamical and group theoretic tools have been used in this research.

Dynamical systems and ergodic theory investigate the evolution of a physical or mathematical system over time, such as the motion of the planets or turbulence in a fluid flow. New ideas and concepts such as chaos and fractals have changed our understanding of the world. Dynamics and ergodic theory provide excellent mathematical tools, and have a strong impact on the sciences and engineering. Symbolic dynamics for instance has been instrumental in developing efficient and safe codes for computer science. Tools and ideas from smooth dynamics are used as far afield as cell biology and meteorology. Geometry is a highly developed and ancient field in mathematics of amazing vigor. It studies curves, surfaces and their higher dimensional analogues, their shapes, shortest paths, and maps between such spaces. Differential geometry had its roots in cartography, starting with Gauss in the nineteenth century. It is closely linked with physics and other sciences and applied areas such as computer vision. Geometry and dynamics are closely related. Indeed, important dynamical systems come from geometry, and vice versa geometry provides tools to study dynamical systems. One main goal of this project studies when two dynamical systems commute, i.e. when one system is unaffected by the changes brought on by the other. Important examples of such systems arise from geometry when the space contains many flat subspaces. Group theory finally enters both dynamics and geometry by studying the group of symmetries of a geometry or dynamical situation, or vice versa by investigating the dynamical and geometric behavior of the group of symmetries acting on a space.

This award supports work on rigidity theorems in geometry and dynamics. The basic goal is to characterize and classify certain objects under very minimal assumptions. This program has its origins in the famous works of Mostow and Margulis from the 1960s which studied a very special class of spaces, the so-called (locally) symmetric spaes.   These are the crown jewels in geometry, the most symmetric of all spaces. Their results  initated the quest for characterizing these spaces by various extremal properties.  At the same time, it was rthe beginning of the Zimmer program that investigates actions of semisimple Lie groups and their lattices.

It is conjectured that locally symmetric spaces are characterized amongst all manifolds with negative curvature bounded below by -1 by the condition that every geodesic is contained in a hyperbolic surface of curvature -1.  In joint work with C. Connell and T. Nguyen, we proved this if the sectional curvature is (non-strictly) pinched between -1/4 and -1.  We recently also proved it for perturbations of certain locally symmetric metrics.  These works use both techniques and tools from differential geometry and  dynamical systems.   In particular, we use the theory of Lyapunov exponents and normal forms for measure preserving diffeomorphisms as well as Carnot geometry (related to control theory in engineering).

This work extends a well-known list of rigidity results of similar flavor, so-called rank rigidity results. This area of research has been active for now thirty years. In particular it complements work from the 1990's by Hamenstaedt who established a similar result if the sectional curvatures are bounded above by -1.

The awardee has further made major progress on symmetries of dynamical systems, particularly the so-called Katok-Spatzier conjecture on commuting flows with  hyperbolic behavior (i.e. exponentially diverging orbits).  With Vinhage, he classified such systems under suitable assumptions in a recent preprint.  The proof introduces new tools which hopefully will lead to major progress on related rigidity problems.  With Yang, the PI also classified commuting expnding maps.

In addition, the PI has worked with Gorodnik on smooth factors of projective actions as well as exponential mixing, a Schur type theorem in Kaehler geometry with Schmidt and Shankar, equilibrium states in dynamics with Visscher and actions on prodcuts of trees with Fisher, Larsen and Stover.

The awardee has also further trained six graduate students and three postdocs in Riemannian gometry and dynamical systems, and has been involved in training and outreach efforts, in particular in inquiry based learning.
